text:
Hi, I have a question to the IJulia.jl.
It uses Conda.jl as a dependency. Conda itself is not free for commercial usage. So in order to use IJulia.jl legally in larger company, one must buy a conda license?

elements.text:
Hi, I have a question to the IJulia.jl.
It uses Conda.jl as a dependency. Conda itself is not free for commercial usage. So in order to use IJulia.jl legally in larger company, one must buy a conda license?

text: Where do you see it’s not free for commercial use? <https://docs.conda.io/en/latest/license.html> states that it’s 3-clause BSD which shouldn’t cause problems regarding commercial use.

elements.text: Where do you see it’s not free for commercial use?
states that it’s 3-clause BSD which shouldn’t cause problems regarding commercial use.

text: here it is: <https://www.anaconda.com/blog/anaconda-commercial-edition-faq>

attachments.title: Anaconda | Anaconda Commercial Edition FAQ
attachments.fallback: Anaconda: Anaconda | Anaconda Commercial Edition FAQ

elements.text: here it is:

text: > And while there will always be a free version of Anaconda for individual hobbyists, academics, non-profits, and small businesses, Commercial Edition also provides an avenue for commercial users to support open-source projects and education through the Anaconda Dividend program.

elements.text: And while there will always be a free version of Anaconda for individual hobbyists, academics, non-profits, and small businesses, Commercial Edition also provides an avenue for commercial users to support open-source projects and education through the Anaconda Dividend program.

text: > [...]  use by individual hobbyists, students, universities, non-profit organizations, or businesses with less than 200 employees is allowed, and all other usage is considered commercial and thus requires a business relationship with Anaconda.

elements.text: [...]  use by individual hobbyists, students, universities, non-profit organizations, or businesses with less than 200 employees is allowed, and all other usage is considered commercial and thus requires a business relationship with Anaconda.

text: so if you have more than 200 employees, your employer should buy a license (I am not a lawyer, this is not legal advice)

elements.text: so if you have more than 200 employees, your employer should buy a license (I am not a lawyer, this is not legal advice)

text:
> You are also not in compliance if you are using mirroring software to create copies of the Anaconda repositories without a license.
That's much more interesting/worrying for redistribution of Conda via Pkg, maybe?

root.text:
Hi, I have a question to the IJulia.jl.
It uses Conda.jl as a dependency. Conda itself is not free for commercial usage. So in order to use IJulia.jl legally in larger company, one must buy a conda license?

elements.text:
Hi, I have a question to the IJulia.jl.
It uses Conda.jl as a dependency. Conda itself is not free for commercial usage. So in order to use IJulia.jl legally in larger company, one must buy a conda license?
You are also not in compliance if you are using mirroring software to create copies of the Anaconda repositories without a license.
That's much more interesting/worrying for redistribution of Conda via Pkg, maybe?

text: Or maybe I'm mixing conda and anaconda together and it's ok to use conda and redistribute it, but not anaconda?

elements.text: Or maybe I'm mixing conda and anaconda together and it's ok to use conda and redistribute it, but not anaconda?

text:
Conda != Anaconda
Conda is the package manager, it's fully open source

Anaconda is a distribution of python and related tool made by Continuum Analytics.
It has Conda, and Python, a ton of libraries preinstalled and I think a editor or two, and it makes heavy use of Conda to install it's parts.
It's not open source, but we don't use it

text:
So, technically, Conda.jl uses Miniconda: <https://github.com/JuliaPy/Conda.jl/blob/dc1c1c77afe796f816a7fae29cacf87cacb56986/src/Conda.jl#L128|https://github.com/JuliaPy/Conda.jl/blob/dc1c1c77afe796f816a7fae29cacf87cacb56986/src/Conda.jl#L128>
```res = "<https://repo.continuum.io/miniconda/Miniconda$(MINICONDA_VERSION)-latest-|https://repo.continuum.io/miniconda/Miniconda$(MINICONDA_VERSION)-latest->"
```
Is Miniconda open-source?

https://repo.continuum.io/miniconda/Miniconda$(MINICONDA_VERSION)-latest-
Is Miniconda open-source?

text:
If Miniconda is not open-source, then if you want to use Conda.jl in commercial usage, you will need to:
1. Figure out what the license and EULA are for Miniconda
2. Make sure that the Miniconda license and EULA permit you to use Miniconda in commercial usage

elements.text: If Miniconda is not open-source, then if you want to use Conda.jl in commercial usage, you will need to:
Figure out what the license and EULA are for Miniconda
Make sure that the Miniconda license and EULA permit you to use Miniconda in commercial usage

text: I'm wondering if this shouldn't be stated somewhere in Conda.jl

elements.text: I'm wondering if this shouldn't be stated somewhere in Conda.jl

text:
The Conda.jl README currently states:
> Instead of the full Anaconda distribution, Conda.jl uses the miniconda Python environment, which only includes conda and its dependencies.
> 
However, it does not mention that Miniconda is not open-source software (i.e. is not licensed under an OSI-approved license), which seems like an important omission.

Want to make a PR to add a note to the README?

elements.text: The Conda.jl README currently states:
Instead of the full Anaconda distribution, Conda.jl uses the miniconda Python environment, which only includes conda and its dependencies.

However, it does not mention that Miniconda is not open-source software (i.e. is not licensed under an OSI-approved license), which seems like an important omission.

Want to make a PR to add a note to the README?

text:
In this link (<https://docs.conda.io/en/latest/miniconda.html|https://docs.conda.io/en/latest/miniconda.html>), Miniconda is described as:
> a small, bootstrap version of Anaconda
> 
If Miniconda is a "version of Anaconda", and Anaconda is not free for commercial usage, I think there is reason to be concerned that Miniconda might not be free for commercial usage.

And also, if by default conda queries <http://repo.anaconda.com|repo.anaconda.com>, if I understood it correctly, the usage of <http://repo.anaconda.com|repo.anaconda.com> for commercial use is licensed, right?

text:
Yeah, the license to use `<http://repo.anaconda.com|repo.anaconda.com>` (<https://www.anaconda.com/terms-of-service|https://www.anaconda.com/terms-of-service>) says:
> we are not granting you permission to use the Repository for commercial activities

attachments.text: Products and pricing for every data scientist. Whether you are a student, or an enterprise, there is an Anaconda product that fits your needs.
